_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary - Clinton Terminal Rail Tank Car Storage Site

Crestwood Midstream Partners has a long- standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Crestwood's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Crestwood has a track lease agreement with Carolina Coastal Railway Inc. for the short-term storage of up to 50 propane railcars in Clinton, North Carolina.

The loaded interconnected railcars fit the EPA's definition of a stationary source in 40 CFR part 68 while disconnected from a means of transportation (i.e.locomotive). The facility contains one source of a regulated substance held over its respective threshold quantity: propane.

General Accident Release Prevention and Program Information

Clinton Terminal Rail Tank Car Storage Site is regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) risk management Program 2 (RMP) regulation. 

Safety Information

Crestwood keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe storage of the regulated substance. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for safe storage of the propane and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. The reference documents are maintained by operations. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). 

Hazard Review

Crestwood has conducted a Hazard Review of the Propane Tank Car Storage process to evaluate the hazards associated with the process. The review identified potential causes for accidental releases, safeguards needed to control hazards and preven

t equipment or human error, and steps needed to detect or monitor releases in order to minimize the potential hazards associated with the storage of propane in tank cars for the intended duration. Crestwood systematically examined each hazard identified in the review to ensure that adequate controls were in place and the potential risk was appropriately mitigated.

Recommendations from Hazard Reviews are prioritized on a relative risk ranking based on Crestwood's Corporate Risk Matrix. The ranking helps ensure that potential hazards assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention. All approved mitigation options in response to Hazard Reviews are prioritized and tracked to completion. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

Operating Procedures

Crestwood conducts no operations at the site. Carolina Coastal Railway Inc. maintains written procedures that address deliveries and shipments for railroad tank cars. The procedures used onsite are written to comply with the Federal Railroad Administration, Department of Transportation regulations under 49 CFR Subtitle B Section II. The procedures are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes.

Training

Crestwood conducts no operations at the site. Carolina Coastal Railway Inc. has implemented a comprehensive training program for all site employees. New employees receive basic training in facility operations if they are not already familiar with such operations and must demonstrate competence. All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training. 

Maintenance

Crestwood does not conduct any maintenance at the site. Carolina Coastal Railway Inc. has established practices and procedures to maintain the facility in safe operating conditions. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting

identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process.

Incident Investigation

If a release of a stationary propane tank car were to occur at Clinton Terminal Rail Tank Car Storage Site,  Carolina Coastal Railway Inc. would initiate the emergency response actions and conduct the incident investigation. Crestwood would not be involved in the emergency response actions or incident investigation or development of the incident report. Crestwood would have access to the incident report once the investigation is completed by the railroad.

Emergency Response Program Information

Carolina Coastal Railway Inc, Inc. follows the Federal Railroad Administration, Department of Transportation regulations under 49 CFR Subtitle B Section II for the movement and storage of tank cars including the tank cars stored by Crestwood at Clinton Terminal Rail Tank Car Storage Site. If a release of propane from a stationary tank car does occur, response actions would be directed by Carolina Coastal Railway Inc. Outside response activities, if deemed necessary,  would be coordinated with the ClintonFire Department and Sampson County Emergency Services.

Five Year Accident History

According to Crestwood personnel, Clinton Terminal Rail Tank Car Storage Site has had no RMP accidents in the last five years.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Crestwood has completed a Hazard Review for the process and has developed an action plan for the findings associated with the triennial compliance audits.
